children.comments: Lift a computation from the base monad.
children.title: liftBase

declarations.comments:
A class for lifting computations in a monad at the bottom of a transformer
stack.

`MonadBase` is a generalization of the concept represented by classes like
`MonadEffect` and `MonadAff`.

Instances should satisfy the following laws, which state that `liftBase`
is a transformer of monads:

```purescript
liftBase <<< pure = pure
liftBase (f =<< m) = liftBase <<< f =<< liftBase m
```
declarations.title: MonadBase

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `liftBase` which is defined as 

```purescript
lift <<< liftBase
```
declarations.title: liftBaseDefault

children.comments:
Run a base monad action with access to a runner function that is capable
of running a monadic action `m` in `b` (strictly speaking, a natural
transformation from `m` to `b`).
children.title: withRunInBase

declarations.comments:
Monads which allow their actions to be run in a base monad.

`MonadUnlift` captures the opposite notion of `MonadBase` - while
`MonadBase` allows any base monad `b` to be lifted into a transformed monad
`m`, `MonadUnlift` allows `m` to be run in `b`, as long as the outer
context is in `m`.

Note that the laws given below require that a monad have no "monadic
state", which essentially limits instances to `ReaderT` and `IdentityT`
stacks.

Instances should satisfy the following laws, which state that
`unlift` is a transformer of monads for any given `u` returned by
`askUnlift`:

```purescript
unlift u <<< pure = pure
unlift u (f =<< m) = unlift u <<< f =<< unlift u m
```
declarations.title: MonadUnlift

declarations.comments: A newtype wrapper around a natural transformation from `m` to `b`.
declarations.title: Unlift

declarations.comments:
Run an action directly in a base monad `b`. Use `askUnlift` or `withUnlift`
to obtain an `Unlift b m` value.
declarations.title: unlift

declarations.comments:
Returns a natural transformation from `m` to `b` within an `m` context.
This can subsequently be used to run `m` actions in the base monad `b`.
declarations.title: askUnlift

declarations.comments:
A monomorphic version of askUnlift which can be more convenient when you
only want to use the resulting runner function once with a concrete type.

If you run into type issues using this, try using `askUnlit` instead.
declarations.title: askRunInBase

declarations.comments:
A version of `withRunInBase` that provides an `Unlift` wrapper instead of
a rank-2 polymorphic function.
declarations.title: withUnlift

declarations.comments: Run the given action inside the base monad `b`.
declarations.title: toBase

children.comments:
Run an `Aff` with access to a runner function that is capable of
running a monadic action `m` in `Aff`.
children.title: withRunInAff

declarations.comments:
Monads which allow their actions to be run in `Aff`.

`MonadUnliftAff` captures the opposite notion of `MonadAff` - while
`MonadAff` allows an `Aff` to be lifted into another monad,
`MonadUnliftAff` allows a monad other than `Aff` to be run in an
`Aff` context.

Note that the laws given below require that a monad have no "monadic
state", which essentially limits instances to `ReaderT` stacks with a
base of `Aff`.

Instances should satisfy the following laws, which state that
`unliftAff` is a transformer of monads for any given `u` returned by
`askUnliftAff`:.

```purescript
unliftAff u <<< pure = pure
unliftAff u (f =<< m) = unliftAff u <<< f =<< unliftAff u m
```
declarations.title: MonadUnliftAff

declarations.comments: A newtype wrapper around a natural transformation from `m` to `Aff`.
declarations.title: UnliftAff

declarations.comments:
Run an action directly in `Aff`. Use `askUnliftAff` or
`withUnliftAff` to obtain an `UnliftAff m` value.
declarations.title: unliftAff

declarations.comments:
Returns a natural transformation from `m` to `Aff` within an `m` context.
This can subsequently be used to run `m` actions directly in `Aff`.
declarations.title: askUnliftAff

declarations.comments:
A monomorphic version of askUnliftAff which can be more convenient when
you only want to use the resulting runner function once with a concrete
type.

If you run into type issues using this, try using `askUnlitAff` instead.
declarations.title: askRunInAff

declarations.comments:
A version of `withRunInAff` that provides an `UnliftAff` wrapper
instead of a rank-2 polymorphic function.
declarations.title: withUnliftAff

declarations.comments: Run the given action inside the `Aff` monad.
declarations.title: toAff

children.comments:
Run an `Effect` with access to a runner function that is capable of
running a monadic action `m` in `Effect`.
children.title: withRunInEffect

declarations.comments:
Monads which allow their actions to be run in `Effect`.

`MonadUnliftEffect` captures the opposite notion of `MonadEffect` - while
`MonadEffect` allows an `Effect` to be lifted into another monad,
`MonadUnliftEffect` allows a monad other than `Effect` to be run in an
`Effect` context.

Note that the laws given below require that a monad have no "monadic
state", which essentially limits instances to `ReaderT` and `IdentityT`
stacks with a base of `Effect`.

Instances should satisfy the following laws, which state that
`unliftEffect` is a transformer of monads for any given `u` returned by
`askUnliftEffect`:

```purescript
unliftEffect u <<< pure = pure
unliftEffect u (f =<< m) = unliftEffect u <<< f =<< unliftEffect u m
```
declarations.title: MonadUnliftEffect

declarations.comments: A newtype wrapper around a natural transformation from `m` to `Effect`.
declarations.title: UnliftEffect

declarations.comments:
Run an action directly in `Effect`. Use `askUnliftEffect` or
`withUnliftEffect` to obtain an `UnliftEffect m` value.
declarations.title: unliftEffect

declarations.comments:
Returns a natural transformation from `m` to `Effect` within an `m` context.
This can subsequently be used to run `m` actions directly in `Effect`.
declarations.title: askUnliftEffect

declarations.comments:
A monomorphic version of askUnliftEffect which can be more convenient when
you only want to use the resulting runner function once with a concrete
type.

If you run into type issues using this, try using `askUnlitEffect` instead.
declarations.title: askRunInEffect

declarations.comments:
A version of `withRunInEffect` that provides an `UnliftEffect` wrapper
instead of a rank-2 polymorphic function.
declarations.title: withUnliftEffect

declarations.comments: Run the given action inside the `Effect` monad.
declarations.title: toEffect
